Biography:

With their Chop Shop Records debut, Where We Are, Mackintosh Braun establish themselves as a formidable pop duo who blend crisp, sophisticated production with sharp, emotive songwriting. Considering that Portland is home to bands as varied as the Decemberists, YACHT, and Modest Mouse, the qualities that seem to define the cityÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s current scene are experimentation and singular sonic vision. And in these ways, there is no more quintessentially Portland band than Mackintosh Braun.

Both Ian Mackintosh and bassist/keyboardist/producer Ben Braun have deep roots in the Pacific Northwest. Ben was born in New York City but moved to Portland with his mom when he was nine. BenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s father was the longtime drummer for Hall & Oates and he instilled in his son an early love of all things music related. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI thought that was so cool.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Ian was also brought up in a musical family. Born in Los Angeles, he grew up in Santa Barbara, then Southern Oregon, before moving to Portland right after high school. Like Ben, it was IanÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s father who inspired his interest in music. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œMy dad was a singer-songwriter who gave it all up to raise a family,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ Ian recalls. ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œHe taught me how to play guitar when I was eleven. We didnÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t have any money but my dad found a way to build a studio at our house.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½

As ambitious young men introduced to the wild world of rock music by their fathers, you would think that both Ben and Ian would be shredding in their bedrooms at sixteen, but instead they both found themselves drawn to the technical side of music: sampling, sequencing, and high-end production. Mesmerized equally by the joyful simplicity of the Bee Gees and the cerebral cool of Orchestral Manoeuvres in the Dark, they both felt compelled to make substantive music that showcased a deep range of influences but that you could also dance to. And itÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s this shared sense of how music should sound that brought them together. Well, that and BenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s dad.

Back in 2006, BenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s father bought a new house through a realtor who knew Ian. The two got to talking about music, IanÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s name came up, a tape was exchanged, and next thing you know Ben was playing IanÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s music in his living room. Even now, when weÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢re writing, heÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ll do something and IÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ll think, ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‹Å“shit, I was going to do that.ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ The pair began making music together. Then, when Ian was evicted from his apartment, he started crashing at BenÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s studio and the band really took off. Following six months of feverish writing and recording, Mackintosh Braun emerged with their self-released debut, The Sound. The album included ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œWake Up,ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ an affecting electro-jam which perfectly captured the sound the duo was going for: ethereal and elegant but also deeply emotional. The track was selected for inclusion on an episode of the TV show Chuck and suddenly Mackintosh Braun had gone from a studio project between two music obsessives to a full-fledged band signed to Chop Shop.

With a record label in place, the band entrenched themselves in the studio and began working on Where We Are. The stakes were higher, but their process remained the same. They recorded the album in a makeshift studio set up in IanÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s house, producing and mixing the entire record themselves. And ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã…â€œI WonÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢t FallÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã‚ï¿½ is a compulsively danceable track with a sing-along chorus.
